doc.ContractDescription: THE FERMI GAMMA-RAY BURST MONITOR (GBM) HAS MADE POSSIBLE A TENACIOUS HUNT FOR RARE, SHORT-LIVED AND HIGHLY ENERGETIC BURSTS. AMONG THESE ARE TWO SPECIAL KINDS OF THERMONUCLEAR EXPLOSIONS ON ACCRETING NEUTRON STARS: LONG DURATION BURSTS AND SUPERBURSTS. WHILE THOUSANDS OF NORMAL DURATION TYPE I X-RAY BURSTS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED IN THE LAST THREE DECADES, ONLY ABOUT A DOZEN EACH SUPERBURSTS AND LONG BURSTS HAVE BEEN DETECTED TO DATE. WE HAVE SET UP A FERMI-GBM ALL-SKY SEARCH FOR X-RAY BURSTS, IN A COORDINATED EFFORT BETWEEN MIT AND NSSTC. IN ONLY 10 MONTHS THIS HAS YIELDED A TOTAL OF 441 X-RAY BURST CANDIDATES, AND AT LEAST 10 LONG DURATION THERMONUCLEAR BURSTS. WE HEREBY REQUEST FUNDS TO REFINE THE ONGOING SEARCH, EXTEND OUR ANALYSIS AND COMPILE A GBM X-RAY BURST CATALOG.
doc.MajorAgency: THE GBM ALL-SKY X-RAY BURST MONITOR
doc.MajorFundingAgency: THE GBM ALL-SKY X-RAY BURST MONITOR

doc.ContractDescription: BASE DESCRIPTION - MULTIPLE YEAR AWARD - FOUR YEAR AWARD INCREMENTALLY FUNDED. THE AWARD IS IN RESPONSE TO COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT NOTICE (CAN) #NNH08ZDA008C, NASA LUNAR SCIENCE INSTITUTE (NSLI), CYCLE ONE. THIS GRANT IS AWARDED TO MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY (MIT), THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR (PI) IS MARIA T. ZUBER, AND THE AWARD IS ENTITLED "LUNAR - THE MOON AS CORNERSTONE TO THE TERRESTRIAL PLANETS." PROJECT SUMMARY FROM PROPOSAL IS: OUR - BROWN/MIT, TEAM (TOGETHER EVERYONE ACHIEVES MORE) HAS IDENTIFIED "TOP TEN SCIENCE QUESTIONS" WITHIN SEVERAL INTEGRATED SCIENCE THEMES THAT WE ARE EAGER TO PURSUE AS PART OF OUR NASA LUNAR SCIENCE INSTITUTE. FROM OUR EXPERIENCE WE KNOW THESE EXAMPLE SCIENCE QUESTIONS ARE EXTREMELY IMPORTANT TO ADDRESS. WE KNOW OUR TEAM HAS EXCEPTIONALLY STRONG BACKGROUND EXPERIENCE, INSIGHT, AND ENTHUSIASM TO ADDRESS THEM. WE ALSO KNOW, HOWEVER, THAT THESE FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS HAVE NO EASY ANSWER, NOR IS THERE A CLEAR FORMULA OF ACTIVITIES THAT WILL RESOLVE THEM. THEY ALL REQUIRE AN INTEGRATION AND DEPTH OF KNOWLEDGE ACROSS FIELDS. FURTHERMORE, WE KNOW THAT ONLY A FEW LUNAR SCIENTISTS HAVE BEEN TRAINED IN MAJOR UNIVERSITY RESEARCH CENTERS OVER THE LAST SEVERAL DECADES, AND THE CURRENT LUNAR SCIENCE COMMUNITY IS THIN AND THUS ILL PREPARED TO ADDRESS SUCH FUNDAMENTAL QUESTIONS IN THE DECADES AHEAD. THE FEEDSTOCK IS JUST NOT THERE. WE PROPOSE TO FIX THIS LACK OF KNOWLEDGEABLE EDUCATORS AND SCIENTISTS. SEE THE PROPOSAL FOR THE COMPLETE RESEARCH ACTIVITY. SPECIAL CONDITION 1260.51 FOR COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT SPECIAL CONDITION. (A) THIS AWARD IS A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AS IT IS ANTICIPATED THERE WILL BE SUBSTANTIAL NASA INVOLVEMENT DURING PERFORMANCE OF THE EFFORT. NASA AND THE RECIPIENT MUTUALLY AGREE TO THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT OF ANTICIPATED COOPERATIVE INTERACTIONS WHICH MAY OCCUR DURING THE PERFORMANCE OF THIS EFFORT: NASA AMES LUNAR SCIENCE INSTITUTE SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FOLLOWING CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE JOINT ACTIVITY: THERE ARE SIX POINTS OF RESPONSIBILITY, SEE THE FILE FOR THE FULL TEXT. THE RECIPIENT/GRANTEE UNIVERSITIES SPACE RESEARCH ASSOCIATION SHALL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PERFORMANCE OF THE FOLLOWING AGREED OBJECTIVES: THERE ARE SIX POINTS OF RESPONSIBILITY, SEE THE FILE FOR THE FULL TEXT. (B) THE TERMS "GRANT" AND "RECIPIENT" MEAN "COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT" AND "RECIPIENT OF COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT," RESPECTIVELY, WHEREVER THE TERMS APPEAR IN PROVISIONS AND SPECIAL CONDITIONS INCLUDED IN THIS AGREEMENT. (C) NASA'S ABILITY TO PARTICIPATE AND PERFORM ITS COLLABORATIVE EFFORT UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS SUBJECT TO THE AVAILABILITY OF APPROPRIATED FUNDS AND NOTHING IN THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT COMMITS THE UNITED STATES CONGRESS TO APPROPRIATE FUNDS THEREFORE.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE A THREE-YEAR PROGRAM OF ALGORITHM AND VALIDATION/VERIFICATION STUDIES FOR OCO-2, TO IMPROVE THE GLOBAL CO2 MEASUREMENTS BY INSURING THAT ADVANCES IN RETRIEVAL ALGORITHMS AND SPECTROSCOPIC AND OTHER REFERENCE DATA ARE FULLY AVAILABLE. THE RESEARCH INCLUDES: DEVELOPMENT OF ON-ORBIT RADIOMETRIC AND SPECTROSCOPIC VERIFICATION; IMPROVED FORWARD MODEL INPUTS; ASSESSING RETRIEVAL ERROR BUDGETS, INCLUDING COVARIANCES AND AVERAGING KERNELS; VALIDATION STRATEGIES FOR LEVEL 2 PRODUCTS; ASSESSMENT OF DATA QUALITY DURING ON-ORBIT CHECKOUT. INDEPENDENT ALGORITHM PHYSICS STUDIES WHICH TEST ASSUMPTIONS AND THEIR IMPLEMENTATION INTO OPERATIONAL PROCESSING INCLUDE: * ANALYSES OF THE SPECTROSCOPIC ASSUMPTIONS (QUALITY OF SPECTRAL DATA AND OF LINE SHAPE PARAMETERIZATION, LINE MIXING, AND COLLISION-INDUCED ABSORPTION) AND THEIR EFFECTS ON THE CO2 ERROR BUDGET. * ASSESSMENT OF ERROR CONTRIBUTIONS FROM ESTIMATES AND MEASUREMENTS OF THE ATMOSPHERIC STATE, INCLUDING CLIMATOLOGIES AND, AFTER LAUNCH, MEASUREMENTS OF TEMPERATURE AND HUMIDITY PROFILES COINCIDENT WITH OCO-2 MEASUREMENTS. * ESTIMATION OF ERROR CONTRIBUTIONS FROM INSTRUMENT CALIBRATION AND CHARACTERIZATION AND INSTRUMENT SAMPLING CHARACTERISTICS AS DETERMINED PRE-FLIGHT AND REVISED AFTER LAUNCH. FLIGHT DATA ANALYSES ALSO INCLUDE IMPROVED ESTIMATES OF THE INSTRUMENT TRANSFER FUNCTION (ITF) AND TESTS OF DETECTOR NONLINEARITY, AND DETECTOR MEMORY EFFECTS. THE SIGNIFICANT OCO-2 UNDERSAMPLING WILL CAUSE ADDITIONAL STRUCTURE IN THE RADIANCE/IRRADIANCE RATIO AS WELL AS LOW-LEVEL DISTORTION OF THE SPECTRA. WE WILL MODEL THIS FOR CORRECTION USING THE IMPROVED HIGH-RESOLUTION IRRADIANCES NOW AVAILABLE AT SAO AND JPL, AS WELL AS THE TERRESTRIAL SPECTRUM, USING THE TECHNIQUES WE HAVE DEVELOPED FOR CORRECTION OF UV/VISIBLE SATELLITE SPECTRA. * APPLICATION OF IMPROVED SOLAR SPECTRUM MODELING. THERE ARE IMPROVED VERSIONS OF THE SAO/KPNO IRRADIANCE IN THE O2 A BAND REGION AND SAO-MODELED IRRADIANCES IN ALL 3 REGIONS. WE WILL STUDY THEIR USE FOR IN-FLIGHT WAVELENGTH CALIBRATION (ALSO INCLUDING TERRESTRIAL SPECTRAL INFORMATION), AND ITF DETERMINATION (INCLUDING STABILITY TESTS ON ITS SHAPE. ALGORITHM VERIFICATION AND VALIDATION STUDIES WITH RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODELING AND RETRIEVALS PROVIDE INDEPENDENT CHECKS ON THE OPERATIONAL ALGORITHM. MULTIPLE SCATTERING RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODELING INCLUDES LINE-BY-LINE, WITH POLARIZATION - RAYLEIGH/RAMAN AND AEROSOL). RETRIEVALS INCLUDE SAO OPTIMAL ESTIMATION WITH ERROR BUDGETS AND ERROR PROPAGATION. STUDIES ARE FOR SELECTED SCENARIOS, INCLUDING VALIDATION SITES, AND SITES SELECTED FOR POTENTIAL CONTAMINATION BY CLOUDS AND AEROSOLS, TO ADDRESS: * HOW ATMOSPHERIC, SPECTROSCOPIC, AND INSTRUMENT ISSUES AFFECT THE ULTIMATE RETRIEVALS OF CO2. * EFFECTS OF CALIBRATION REQUIREMENT UNCERTAINTIES AND INSTRUMENT DEGRADATION ON RETRIEVALS OF CO2. * WHAT ALTERNATE CHOICES IN FITTING WINDOWS AND FITTING PROCEDURES MIGHT BE MADE. THIS PROPOSAL RESPONDS TO THE NASA 2011 STRATEGIC PLAN GOAL 2: EXPAND SCIENTIFIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE EARTH AND THE UNIVERSE IN WHICH WE LIVE, ADDRESSING OUTCOME 2.1: ADVANCE EARTH SYSTEM SCIENCE TO MEET THE CHALLENGES OF CLIMATE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE. OUR RESEARCH WILL IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE OF CLIMATE FORCING AND THE GLOBAL CARBON CYCLE BY IMPROVING THE QUANTITATIVE DETERMINATION OF CO2 SOURCES AND SINKS AS MEASURED BY THE OCO-2 INSTRUMENT. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH BUILDS ON THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR'S ROLE AS A MEMBER OF THE ORIGINAL OCO INDEPENDENT REVIEW TEAM AS WELL AS THE LATER OCO CORRECTIVE ACTION REVIEW COMMITTEE, FORMED TO ADDRESS OCO DIFFICULTIES PRE-LAUNCH. IT EXPLOITS THE TREMENDOUS EXPERTISE OF THE SAO PROPOSAL TEAM IN DEVELOPING ALGORITHM PHYSICS AND ADVANCED SATELLITE OPERATIONAL AND RESEARCH ALGORITHMS. THE RESEARCH WILL DEVELOP IMPROVEMENTS IN ALGORITHMS AND ANALYSIS WHICH WILL IMPROVE THE ULTIMATE QUALITY AND UTILITY OF THE OCO-2 DATA PRODUCTS.
doc.MajorAgency: SAO MEMBERSHIP IN THE OCO-2 SCIENCE TEAM
doc.MajorFundingAgency: SAO MEMBERSHIP IN THE OCO-2 SCIENCE TEAM

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE DETAILED LABORATORY STUDIES AIMED AT MEASURING THE RATES AND PRODUCTS OF HETEROGENEOUS REACTIONS BETWEEN ORGANIC RADICALS AND HAZE PARTICLES IMPORTANT IN THE PHOTOCHEMISTRY OF PLANETARY ATMOSPHERES SUCH AS TITAN, SATURN, AND JUPITER. SUCH REACTIONS MAY PLAY A CENTRAL ROLE IN THE CHEMISTRY OF SUCH ATMOSPHERES BY BOTH (1) SERVING AS A SINK FOR ORGANIC RADICALS, AFFECTING THEIR CONCENTRATIONS AND THEREFORE THE RATES OF THEIR OTHER REACTIONS AND (2) ALTERING THE LOADING AND COMPOSITION OF THE HAZE PARTICLES, THEREBY PLAYING A MAJOR ROLE IN THEIR FORMATION AND CHEMICAL/PHYSICAL EVOLUTION. WHILE THE GAS-PHASE ORGANIC CHEMISTRY LEADING TO THE FORMATION OF COMPLEX ORGANIC MOLECULES AND HAZES HAS BEEN THE FOCUS OF EXTENSIVE RESEARCH, HETEROGENEOUS REACTIONS HAVE RECEIVED FAR LESS DIRECT STUDY. IN PARTICULAR, THE LOW-TEMPERATURE RATES AND PRODUCTS - AND THEREFORE THE ATMOSPHERIC IMPLICATIONS - OF REACTIONS OF ORGANIC RADICALS WITH HAZE PARTICLES ARE UNKNOWN AT PRESENT. THE WORK PROPOSED HERE IS AIMED GAINING A DETAILED, QUANTITATIVE UNDERSTANDING OF SUCH REACTIONS FOR THE FIRST TIME, WITH THE GOAL OF UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECTS OF ORGANIC RADICALS ON HAZE PARTICLES AND VICE VERSA. STUDIES WILL BE CARRIED OUT USING AN ENTRAINED AEROSOL FLOW REACTOR CAPABLE OF REACHING LOW TEMPERATURES. HAZE PARTICLES WILL BE GENERATED BY PHOTOLYZING SIMPLE HYDROCARBONS IN A PRE-REACTOR. ONCE IN THE FLOW TUBE, THE PARTICLES WILL BE EXPOSED TO THE ORGANIC RADICALS, GENERATED BY THE UV PHOTOLYSIS OF GAS-PHASE PRECURSOR MOLECULES (ORGANIC HALIDES). THE FOCUS OF THIS WORK IS RADICAL SPECIES CONTAINING 1-4 CARBON ATOMS (CH3, CN, C2H, CCN, HCCN, C3N, AND C4H). KINETICS AND PRODUCTS WILL BE QUANTIFIED IN REAL TIME BY MEASURING CHANGES TO THE GAS AND PARTICLES USING STATE-OF-THE-ART ANALYTICAL TECHNIQUES. IN ADDITION TO THE MEASUREMENTS OF KEY PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF THE PARTICLES (MASS AND SURFACE AREA), THE CHEMICAL COMPOSITION OF ORGANICS IN THE GAS AND PARTICLE PHASES WILL BE MONITORED USING TWO MASS SPECTROMETERS. BOTH UTILIZE HIGH-RESOLUTION ELECTRON IMPACT MASS SPECTROMETRY, A UNIVERSAL TECHNIQUE THAT ALLOWS FOR THE QUANTIFICATION OF TOTAL ORGANIC SPECIES AND ELEMENTAL RATIOS. IN SOME EXPERIMENTS, TUNABLE VACUUM ULTRAVIOLET LIGHT WILL BE COUPLED TO BOTH INSTRUMENTS FOR THE SOFT IONIZATION OF ORGANICS, ENABLING DETECTION OF INDIVIDUAL SPECIES. RATES AND PRODUCTS OF REACTIONS WILL BE MEASURED AS A FUNCTION OF BOTH TEMPERATURE AND CHEMICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE HAZE PARTICLES. THIS WORK BUILDS DIRECTLY ON THE RESEARCH TEAM'S RECENT WORK, WHICH INCLUDES THE MEASUREMENT OF RATES AND PRODUCTS OF HETEROGENEOUS REACTIONS BETWEEN GAS-PHASE RADICALS AND ORGANIC PARTICLES, USING AEROSOL FLOW REACTORS; MEASUREMENT OF THE MOLECULAR COMPOSITION AND ELEMENTAL RATIOS OF COMPLEX ORGANIC PARTICULATE MATTER; AND THE FORMATION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF ORGANIC HAZE PARTICLES IN THE LABORATORY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS DIRECTLY RELEVANT TO ONE OF NASA'S PRIMARY OBJECTIVES IN SOLAR SYSTEM EXPLORATION, UNDERSTANDING THE DISTRIBUTION AND BEHAVIOR OF ORGANIC MATERIAL IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM. IT IS PARTICULARLY ALIGNED WITH THE SCIENTIFIC GOALS OF THE CASSINI-HUYGENS MISSION AND THE PLANNED TITAN SATURN SYSTEM MISSION, INVOLVING THE IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF ORGANIC CHEMISTRY AND HAZE FORMATION IN TITAN'S ATMOSPHERE. KEY OUTPUTS OF THIS WORK, SUCH AS HETEROGENEOUS REACTION PROBABILITIES AND RADICAL-ASSISTED PARTICLE GROWTH RATES, WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE GREATER PLANETARY ATMOSPHERES COMMUNITY, SO THAT HETEROGENEOUS ORGANIC RADICAL-PARTICLE INTERACTIONS CAN BE INCLUDED IN DETAILED PHOTOCHEMICAL MODELS OF PLANETARY ATMOSPHERES FOR THE FIRST TIME. IT IS HOPED THAT RESULTS FROM THIS WORK WILL LEAD TO AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE ATMOSPHERES' MULTIPHASE CHEMISTRY, AND ULTIMATELY THE IMPLICATIONS OF SUCH CHEMISTRY FOR ATMOSPHERIC DYNAMICS AND STRUCTURE, SURFACE CHEMISTRY, AND CLIMATE.
doc.MajorAgency: HETEROGENEOUS CHEMISTRY OF ORGANIC HAZE IN PLANETA
doc.MajorFundingAgency: HETEROGENEOUS CHEMISTRY OF ORGANIC HAZE IN PLANETA
